abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Land Administration
            Project for Nicaragua were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was moderate, Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the sustainability of outcomes of land administration
            interventions requires building broad social and political
            commitment, as well as maintaining and mainstreaming key
            competencies across electoral cycles. The complexity of
            recognizing indigenous people's land rights requires
            attention to historical and social particularities and
            intensive social supervision. Improving a land
            administration system involves gradual changes in the legal
            and institutional frameworks. A strong focus on
            municipalities is critical to the sustainability of
            investments on cadaster and registry modernization in
            Nicaragua. Alternative conflict resolution (ACR) mechanisms
            can effectively facilitate cadastral and regularization processes.
